abstract.p: British Telecommunications PLC's finance director Robert Brace resigns; will be replaced by Philip Hampton (S)

block.p: British Telecommunications, which has been facing mounting criticism as its debt balloons, said today that its finance director was stepping down.

The departure of the executive, Robert Brace, comes amid shareholder calls for a management shake-up. But a British Telecommunications spokeswoman said Mr. Brace's decision to leave the company after 11 years had been planned for some time and was unrelated to the company's financial situation.
British Telecommunications, which has been facing mounting criticism as its debt balloons, said today that its finance director was stepping down.

The departure of the executive, Robert Brace, comes amid shareholder calls for a management shake-up. But a British Telecommunications spokeswoman said Mr. Brace's decision to leave the company after 11 years had been planned for some time and was unrelated to the company's financial situation.
She also denied recent reports in the British press that the company's chairman, Sir Iain Vallance, would be stepping down.
Still, shares of British Telecommunications, which have traded near an annual low, surged 7.7 percent, to 740 pence, or $10.70, in London today.
The company's debt is expected to balloon to $:30 billion, or $44 billion, by the end of next year, or nearly triple March levels. Over the last year and a half, its debt rating has fallen six rungs.

''A year ago, B.T. had one of the strongest balance sheets among European telecom operators,'' said Subhajit Gupta, an analyst with Standard & Poor's in London. ''Today, it's at the bottom end of the group.''

Like other telecommunications companies in Europe, British Telecommunications has been spending heavily to acquire third-generation mobile phone licenses and upgrade its network. Mr. Gupta estimates that over the next two years, the company will spend $25 billion on these new services alone.

Yet unlike its competitors, British Telecommunications has been slow to spin off fast-growing units to foot the bill. The company is expected to conclude a lengthy strategic review by the end of the year. A likely outcome could be an offering of shares in its mobile-phone unit.
Mr. Brace will be replaced by Philip Hampton, 47, group finance director at BG Group, the utility holding company.
